# next

**Instance Property**

Returns the next responder in the responder chain, or `nil` if there’s no next responder.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor var next: UIResponder? { get }
```

## Return Value

The next object in the responder chain, or `nil` if this is the last object in the chain.

## Discussion

The [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIResponder] class doesn’t store or set the next responder automatically, so this method returns `nil` by default. Subclasses must override this method and return an appropriate next responder. For example, [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIView] implements this method and returns the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIViewController] object that manages it (if it has one) or its superview (if it doesn’t). [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIViewController] similarly implements the method and returns its view’s superview. [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIWindow] returns the application object. The shared [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIApplication] object normally returns `nil`, but it returns its app delegate if that object is a subclass of [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIResponder] and hasn’t already been called to handle the event.

## Managing the responder chain

- **isFirstResponder**: Returns a Boolean value indicating whether this object is the first responder.
- **canBecomeFirstResponder**: Returns a Boolean value indicating whether this object can become the first responder.
- **becomeFirstResponder()**: Asks UIKit to make this object the first responder in its window.
- **canResignFirstResponder**: Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the responder is willing to relinquish first-responder status.
- **resignFirstResponder()**: Notifies this object that it has been asked to relinquish its status as first responder in its window.
